Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket as I hauled another bag of cement across the site. I knew it was Mom—she always texted around this time, wanting to know how my day was going. Ever since I started working construction, I made it a point to reply quickly, sending her little updates and photos so she wouldn’t worry. But today, the foreman had just posted a notice about an optional training session next week. He said it would help us work safer and maybe even open up new responsibilities. The catch? It was scheduled right during the hour I usually called home. I could already hear my dad’s voice, “We just want to hear from you, son.” At the same time, I pictured my crew, expecting me to step up and show I was serious about the job. My hands itched to text my parents, but I couldn’t ignore the pressure to be a reliable team member. The two worlds tugged at me, each expecting something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
